Package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost

Interface InHostMarkovState

All Superinterfaces:
InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel>, Serializable
@Immutable public interface InHostMarkovState extends InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel>
A discrete-time Markov chain model of in-host disease and symptom progression.

This model tracks two independent state machines:

  • Disease state: SUSCEPTIBLE → EXPOSED → INFECTIOUS → IMMUNE,
  • Symptom state: ASYMPTOMATIC → SYMPTOMATIC → HOSPITALISED → DEAD.

Transitions are governed by daily probabilities defined in InHostMarkovState.InHostMarkovStateMachine. The model assumes binary immunity: once immune, individuals are fully protected unless waning occurs.

The viral load, severity, and immune activity are derived from the current state, enabling integration with transmission and calibration modules. This approach sacrifices biological detail for computational efficiency and direct mapping to observable epidemiological rates (e.g., IFR, HFR).

See Also:
  • InHostMarkovState.InHostMarkovStateMachine
  • Poisson Binomial Distribution

  • Method Details

    • getDiseaseState

      InHostMarkovState.DiseaseState getDiseaseState()
      Getters for the current disease and symptom states, and the Markov state machine.

      These provide access to the individual's current position in the disease and symptom progression, as well as the transition probabilities defined in the Markov model. The disease and symptom states evolve independently according to their respective transition rules, but are both influenced by the underlying MarkovStateMachine which governs the probabilities of moving between states.

      Returns:
      the current disease state, symptom state, and Markov state machine

    • getImmuneActivity

      default double getImmuneActivity()
      Returns immune activity as a binary indicator.

      Defined as: \[ I(t) = \begin{cases} 1.0 & \text{if } \text{disease state} = \text{IMMUNE} \\ 0.0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \] This reflects full protection during the immune state, with no partial immunity.

      Specified by:
      getImmuneActivity in interface InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel>
      Returns:
      1.0 if immune, 0.0 otherwise

    • getMachine

      @Redacted InHostMarkovState.InHostMarkovStateMachine getMachine()
      Returns the Markov state machine that defines the transition probabilities for both disease and symptom progression. This machine encapsulates the time-homogeneous transition rates between states, allowing for calibration from epidemiological data. The transition probabilities govern how individuals move through the disease states (e.g., from EXPOSED to INFECTIOUS) and symptom states (e.g., from ASYMPTOMATIC to SYMPTOMATIC) on a daily basis. The machine's methods are used in the update logic to determine the next state based on the current state and random sampling.
      Returns:
      the Markov state machine containing transition probabilities for disease and symptom progression
      See Also:
      • InHostMarkovState.InHostMarkovStateMachine

    • getNormalisedSeverity

      @Derived default double getNormalisedSeverity()
      Samples a continuous severity score from a uniform distribution based on symptom state.

      The score is calibrated so that:

      • Case rate: \( \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_c) = r_c \),
      • Hospitalization rate: \( \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_h) = r_h \),
      • Fatality rate: \( \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_f) = r_f \),
      where \( r_c, r_h, r_f \) are the infection-case, infection-hospitalization, and infection-fatality ratios.

      For example: \[ S \sim \text{Uniform}(1 - r_h, 1 - r_f) \quad \text{if } \text{HOSPITALISED} \] This ensures the population-level event rates match input parameters.

      Specified by:
      getNormalisedSeverity in interface InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel>
      Returns:
      a sampled severity value in [0,1]

    • getNormalisedViralLoad

      default double getNormalisedViralLoad()
      Returns a fixed normalized viral load based on disease state.

      Defined as: \[ V_{\text{norm}} = \begin{cases} 1.5 & \text{if } \text{state} = \text{INFECTIOUS} \\ 0.5 & \text{if } \text{state} = \text{EXPOSED} \\ 0.0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \] This coarse proxy enables transmission modeling without detailed viral kinetics.

      Specified by:
      getNormalisedViralLoad in interface InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel>
      Returns:
      a state-dependent normalized viral load

    • getSymptomState

      InHostMarkovState.SymptomState getSymptomState()
      The symptom state is conditional on the disease state, but evolves independently according to its own transition probabilities defined in the MarkovStateMachine. For example, an individual may be in the INFECTIOUS disease state but remain ASYMPTOMATIC in terms of symptoms, and then transition to SYMPTOMATIC based on the probability defined for that transition. The symptom progression is thus a separate layer of the model that captures clinical outcomes without directly affecting the underlying disease state transitions.
      Returns:
      the current symptom state of the individual

    • getTime

      int getTime()
      Returns the current time step in the in-host progression.
      Specified by:
      getTime in interface InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel>
      Returns:
      the current time step (e.g., days since infection) in the in-host progression

    • update

      default InHostMarkovState update(Sampler sampler, double virionExposure, double immunisationDose)
      Advances the in-host state by one time step using Markov transitions.

      The update logic:

      1. If currently SUSCEPTIBLE and exposed to virions: → EXPOSED,
      2. If currently SUSCEPTIBLE and immunized: → IMMUNE,
      3. Otherwise: apply Markov transitions from current disease and symptom states.

      Disease progression uses Bernoulli and multinomial sampling: \[ \mathbb{P}(X_{t+1} = x') = \sum_{x} \mathbb{P}(X_t = x) \cdot p(x \to x') \] where transition probabilities are constant per day.

      The use of Sampler.bern(Double, Object) and Sampler.multinom(Pair...) ensures independent stochastic realizations. The sum of such independent transitions aligns with the framework of the Poisson binomial distribution when aggregating over populations, where each individual has a potentially different path through the state space.

      Specified by:
      update in interface InHostModelState<MarkovStateModel>
      Parameters:
      sampler - the random sampler for stochastic transitions
      virionExposure - non-zero if the individual is exposed to infectious virions
      immunisationDose - non-zero if the individual receives an immunizing dose (e.g., vaccine)
      Returns:
      a new state advanced by one time unit
